thread.title: Right Track, with racing experts Lincoln Moore Ben Scadden | The Advertiser
thread.title_full: The Right Track, with Advertiser racing experts Lincoln Moore and Ben Scadden | The Advertiser

author: LINCOLN MOORE, BEN SCADDEN
title: Right Track, with racing experts Lincoln Moore Ben Scadden | The Advertiser
text:
TOURNEUR NEARS RACE RETURN
DOM Tourneur is making steady progress in his recovery from a bulging disc problem in his back and hopes to return to the races within a couple of weeks.
Tourneur hasn’t ridden since the Morphettville meeting on June 6 and was virtually housebound for several weeks, with his mobility significantly affected..
The hoop returned to riding trackwork this week and rode a half-dozen horses at Morphettville on Thursday.
“I’ll ride work again on Saturday then make a decision if I try to come back into next week or maybe the week after,” Tourneur said. “It’s starting to feel a bit better but, by the same token, it’s still a little niggly.”
SUE SEALS LIMESTONE TITLE
SUE Murphy has won the Limestone Coast trainers’ premiership, despite going winless at Sunday’s Penola meeting.
Murphy finished the local season with 18 wins, one clear of Sue Jaensch, who trained Helandy to victory at Penola. Michael O’Leary trained a double to claim third on the premiership table with 16 wins.
Holly McKechnie (17 wins) was a clear winner over the jockeys’ title, while a treble at Penola gave Emily Finnegan the apprentice premiership. She finished with 14 wins, two clear of Caitlin Jones.
JOCKEY SWAPS IN SA
THERE’S been plenty of movement in the South Australian jockey manager ranks recently.
Two of the state’s best — Jason Holder and Joe Bowditch — are now being managed by former jockey Cheree Gask.
Gask also has Jamie Kah on her books, the former top apprentice riding work for Gask’s brother-in-law Jeremy in England this week in preparation for her return to race riding in the new season.
And Damien Wilton, who manages the state’s leading rider Clare Lindop, is now managing up-and-coming apprentice Emily Finnegan.
NO CLARITY ON VIC VISION
THERE’S no clear solution in sight for the vision issues that means many people cannot watch Victorian races at home.
Regional areas and city residents with older TVs are growing increasingly frustrated that they cannot access Channel 78 pictures.
Tabcorp has not shown Victorian racing on Sky Channel in pubs and homes since its contract expired on June 15.
Racing Victoria and its free-to-air media partner, the Seven Network, are continuing negotiations to beam vision into rural areas via Foxtel.
RV executives are also having ongoing discussions with Sky/TAB.
But there’s no indication they’re closing on a resolution.
CHROME DULLED BY INJURY
AMERICAN super horse California Chrome may not race again.
The 2014 Kentucky Derby winner has a bruised cannon bone and there’s a chance he could be retired.
“It’s not life threatening or anything, but it looks like he’ll be out for the rest of the year,” trainer Art Sherman told Daily Racing Form.
The horse was due to run in last month’s Group 1 Prince of Wales’ Stakes at Royal Ascot over 2000m but was scratched after suffering a foot abscess.
SAINTS & SINNERS
SAINTS
YVONNE FORREST
Lovely to see her win with Mrs Mariella at Murray Bridge.
ZAC SPAIN
Well-deserved first metropolitan winner with Brimming.
SINNERS
HOSTILE
Plenty of support again but failed to deliver.
HERENOA
Best to steer clear of him on really heavy going.
